Boston.com
10

Fire paralyzes Back Bay

Flames from the Back Bay fire could be seen in this photo taken from Dalton Street with Kings bowling alley in the foreground. Yoon S. Byun/ Globe Staff
Smoke was visible rising above the Boston skyline in this photo taken from the Squantum section of Quincy. Stan Grossfeld / Globe Staff
Thick smoke engulfed part of Boylston Street after the fire broke out. Pictured: Pedestrians walked along Boylston Street. Yoon S. Byun/ Globe Staff
After the blaze was first reported, firefighters worked to gain entry to the garage next to the Back Bay Hilton. Alexandre Isobe for The Boston Globe
Another photo showing smoke from the Back Bay fire was taken near Abe and Louie's restaurant on Boylston Street. Cliff Atiyeh / Globe Staff
People stood along Boylston Street, parts of which were without power overnight. Yoon S. Byun / Globe Staff
The Back Bay skyline was filled with smoke from the fire as seen in this photo taken on Newbury Street. Taylor Aldredge / tayloraldredge.com
  • Boston getting power back | Pictures from the scene
  • Video Thousands in dark | Quinn: People civil
  • Timeline: Reports and photos on the outages, fire

Santorum wins Alabama, Mississippi primaries; Romney takes Hawaii

A resurgent Rick Santorum swept primaries in Alabama and Mississippi Tuesday night, upending the race for the Republican presidential nomination yet again. (AP)

Analysis

Gingrich loses logic for staying in race

With back-to-back losses on Tuesday in the Deep South, Newt Gingrich suffered a third defeat: a rationale for continuing his presidential candidacy. (Boston.com)

Growing income gap threatens area

The disparity between Boston's top earners and its poorest workers has widened and will continue to grow, unless the region's educational system is improved, according to the nonprofit Boston Foundation. (Globe)
Opinion > Jeff Jacoby

No equal justice in 'hate crime'

Hate crime laws have always been problematic. In a nation dedicated to "equal justice under law" the criminal code should not pick and choose among equal victims. (Boston Globe)
